title: 107_s1106
content: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section for a credit for producing Indian oil or gas. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a credit for producing Indian oil or gas. The credit is equal to $6.12 multiplied by the barrel-of-oil equivalent of Indian oil or gas sold to an unrelated person during the taxable year. There are limitations and adjustments, including a phaseout of the credit based on the reference price for the calendar year. The credit for producing Indian oil or gas is subject to adjustments based on inflation and limitations based on the amount of tax. Excess credits can be carried back or carried over to future taxable years. The excess credit for a taxable year can be carried back three years and carried forward 20 years. The entire excess credit amount for a year is carried to the first year. The excess credit for a taxable year can be carried back three years and carried forward 20 years. The excess credit for an excess credit year is carried to the earliest of the 23 taxable years, and any remaining amount is carried to the other 22 years to the extent it cannot be used in prior years due to limitations. The term 'Indian oil or gas' refers to oil or gas produced. The term 'Indian oil or gas' refers to oil or gas produced from deposits held by the United States for the benefit of Indian tribes or individuals, pursuant to a lease or agreement approved by the United States. The term 'Indian tribe' includes various groups owning land held in trust by the United States. The term 'individual Indian' refers to any member of an Indian tribe or Alaska Native recognized as eligible for special programs and services provided by the United States under Federal law. An individual Indian is a member of an Indian tribe or Alaska Native with land held in trust by the United States or subject to restrictions on alienation. Inflation adjustment factor and reference price are determined for each calendar year. Definitions for 'barrel-of-oil equivalent' and 'barrel' are provided. Certain rules from section 29(d) are applicable. The section applies to Indian oil or gas produced after December 31, 2001, excluding cases where a credit is allowed under section 29 for the taxable year. Amendments to the Alternative Minimum Tax are made for taxpayers eligible for the Indian oil or gas credit under section 29A. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the Indian oil or gas credit under section 29A. This includes changes to the Alternative Minimum Tax for eligible taxpayers. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code include a credit for producing Indian oil or gas under section 29A, effective for taxable years ending after December 31, 2001, and for carrybacks from those years.
